required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on November 19, 2021
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Long-term Effectiveness of Abdominal Sacrocolpopexy for the Treatment of Pelvic Organ Prolapse
clinical_study.official_title: Long-term Effectiveness of Abdominal Sacrocolpopexy for the Treatment of Pelvic Organ Prolapse: The Extended Colpopexy and Urinary Reduction Efforts (E-CARE) Study

collaborator.agency: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill
Eunice Kennedy Shriver National Institute of Child Health and Human Development (NICHD)

brief_summary.textblock: The Colpopexy and Urinary Reduction Effort (CARE) trial is a research study designed to evaluate whether the addition of a second surgical procedure in addition to a procedure for female pelvic organ prolapse (POP) affects the rates of urinary incontinence. This study will follow women in the CARE study for 10 years from the time of the surgery to compare success and complication rates in the two groups. Recruitment into this study is open only to women that already participated in CARE. Recruitment into CARE is closed.

clinical_study.why_stopped: resource and prioritization change as Network transition to a new funding cycle

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Anatomic Failure (Original Definition)
primary_outcome.description: Reoperation or pessary for POP or POP-Q measurements as follows: Vaginal apex decends >= 2 cm, or the anterior or posterior vaginal wall decends >1 cm beyond the hymen

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants Considered as Failures For Urinary Incontinence Using the Incontinence Severity Index
primary_outcome.description: Failure is indicated by a score of 3 or greater on the Incontinence Severity Index (formerly called Hunskaar). The score is calculated as the product of the answers to two incontinence-related questions resulting in a range from 0 to 12 (higher scores indicating more severe symptoms). A score of 3 or greater corresponds to a severity classification of moderate, severe, or very severe.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of Participants With Stress Urinary Incontinence (SUI) Prevention
primary_outcome.description: One or more SUI symptoms reported on the Pelvic Floor Distress Inventory, receipt of interval anti-incontinence surgery, or receipt of an urethral bulking agent injection for SUI

arm_group.arm_group_label: Abdominal Sacral Colpopexy with no Burch colposuspension
arm_group.description: Participants had an Abdominal Sacral Colpopexy without Burch colposuspension for treatment of pelvic organ prolapse

arm_group.arm_group_label: Abdominal Sacral Colpopexy with Burch Colposuspension
arm_group.description: Participants had an Abdominal Sacral Colpopexy with Burch colposuspension for treatment of pelvic organ prolapse

study_pop.textblock: Women who completed the CARE study

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Women enrolled in CARE
Exclusion Criteria:
- Inability to provide informed consent.
- Subjects who, at the time of enrollment into E-CARE, are long-term residents of a skilled nursing facility (that is, residency is not limited to short-term rehabilitation).

facility.name: The University of Alabama at Birmingham

measure.title: Age
Sex/Gender, Customized
Race/Ethnicity, Customized
Race/Ethnicity, Customized
Married or living as married
Education level
Number of vaginal deliveries
Number of cesarean deliveries
Number of previous births
Hysterectomy
Prior SUI Surgery
Prior POP Surgery
Pelvic Organ Prolapse-Q stage
measure.description: The POP-Q assessment is a tool that measures the severity of prolapse. It measures nine points in the vagina with the hymen being the reference point. The distance to the reference point (in cm) is measured and the prolapse severity stage is calculated based on those measures. Higher stages indicate worse prolapse.

measure.title: Body Mass Index
BMI >= 30 (obesity)

outcome.title: Number of Participants With Symptomatic Failure
outcome.description: Symptom of bulge on Pelvic Floor Distress Inventory, interval prolapse surgery, or pessary used after index surgery
outcome.population: This outcome is analyzed in randomized participants who completed the visit at this time point, or who were failures prior to the time point. Excluded from the analyses are prior dropouts who had not yet met the failure criteria.

outcome.title: Number of Participants With Anatomic Failure (Original Definition)
outcome.description: Reoperation or pessary for POP or POP-Q measurements as follows: Vaginal apex decends >= 2 cm, or the anterior or posterior vaginal wall decends >1 cm beyond the hymen
outcome.population: This outcome is analyzed in randomized participants who completed the visit at this time point, or who were failures prior to the time point. Excluded from the analyses are prior dropouts who had not yet met the failure criteria. The original and updated versions of anatomic failure could have different denominators for the same time point because a prior anatomic failure means the patient is assigned a failure in all subsequent visits regardless of whether the patient had completed the visits.

Excluded from the analyses are prior dropouts who had not yet met the failure criteria. The original and updated versions of anatomic failure could have different denominators for the same time point because a prior anatomic failure means the patient is assigned a failure in all subsequent visits regardless of whether the patient had completed the visits.

outcome.title: Number of Participants With Anatomic Failure (Updated Definition)
outcome.description: Reoperation or pessary for POP or POP-Q measurements as follows: Vaginal apex descends below the upper third of the vagina, or the anterior (Ba) or posterior (Bp) vaginal wall prolapses beyond the hymen
outcome.population: This outcome is analyzed in randomized participants who completed the visit at this time point, or who were failures prior to the time point. Excluded from the analyses are prior dropouts who had not yet met the failure criteria. The original and updated versions of anatomic failure could have different denominators for the same time point because a prior anatomic failure means the patient is assigned a failure in all subsequent visits regardless of whether the patient had completed the visits.

measure.title: Number of Participants With Composite Failure

outcome.title: Number of Participants Considered as Failures For Urinary Incontinence Using the Incontinence Severity Index
outcome.description: Failure is indicated by a score of 3 or greater on the Incontinence Severity Index (formerly called Hunskaar). The score is calculated as the product of the answers to two incontinence-related questions resulting in a range from 0 to 12 (higher scores indicating more severe symptoms). A score of 3 or greater corresponds to a severity classification of moderate, severe, or very severe.
outcome.population: This outcome is analyzed in randomized participants who completed the visit at this time point, or who were failures prior to the time point. Excluded from the analyses are prior dropouts who had not yet met the failure criteria.

outcome.title: Number of Participants With Stress Urinary Incontinence (SUI) Prevention
outcome.description: One or more SUI symptoms reported on the Pelvic Floor Distress Inventory, receipt of interval anti-incontinence surgery, or receipt of an urethral bulking agent injection for SUI
outcome.population: This outcome is analyzed in randomized participants who completed the visit at this time point, or who were failures prior to the time point. Excluded from the analyses are prior dropouts who had not yet met the failure criteria.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
